results.snippet: An article on Friday about the reaction of Auburn University football fans to the team's success amid controversy surrounding its starting quarterback misidentified the Apollo mission that Ken Mattingly, an astronaut and noted Auburn alumnus,...
results.lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the reaction of Auburn University football fans to the team's success amid controversy surrounding its starting quarterback misidentified the Apollo mission that Ken Mattingly, an astronaut and noted Auburn alumnus, participated in. It was Apollo 16 -- not Apollo 13, which he missed because of health concerns. The article also referred incorrectly to several Auburn flags that Mattingly carried with him on the mission. He never planted one of them on the moon. (As command module pilot of Apollo 16, he did not set foot on the moon.)

results.abstract: Dragon spacecraft and Falcon 9 rocket launched by Space Exploration Technology Corporation flawlessly returns to Earth from orbit in first commercial flight ever; SpaceX founder Elon Musk affirms that mission's success is good start to relationship with National Aeronautics Space Association, which has contract with company to ferry cargo, and perhaps astronauts, to and from International Space Station; photo (M)

headline.main: Private Spacecraft Returns From Orbit for First Time

results.snippet: The capsule’s splashdown in the Pacific Ocean went as smoothly as the launching of the Falcon 9 rocket.
results.lead_paragraph: For the first time, a commercial spacecraft gently returned to Earth from orbit on Wednesday. The flight, by the Space Exploration Technologies Corporation, or SpaceX, went flawlessly from the launching of its Falcon 9 rocket, with a Dragon capsule riding on top, from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida to splashdown of the Dragon in the Pacific Ocean 3 hours, 19 minutes and 52 seconds later.

results.abstract: Time-Life releases DVD collection of 1970s TV show The Six Million Dollar Man, starring Lee Majors; photo (M)

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: SIX MILLION DOLLAR MAN, THE (TV PROGRAM)

results.snippet: Relief for all of those fans who couldn’t even watch reruns of the ’70s hit “Six Million Dollar Man” starring Lee Majors.
results.lead_paragraph: ON many a dull day in the mid-1970s uncounted youths (yes, this one included) would run in slow motion, pretend to bend steel bars with their bare fists and, squinting toward the horizon, emit a noise that might be rendered in print as a soft, staccato beh-beh-beh-beh-beh-beh-beh-beh-beh-beh-beh-beh-beh-beh-beh-beh. They were, of course, emulating the ABC series ''The Six Million Dollar Man.'' For five seasons the show's protagonist, Col. Steve Austin (played by Lee Majors), didn't merely foil evildoers with his atomically powered bionic legs, right arm and left eye. He did so amid some of the world's coolest sound effects while wearing a most colorful array of leisure suits.

results.snippet: “Tron: Legacy,” Disney’s 3-D sequel to the 1982 “Tron,” picks up with far less color and cinematic imagination, and many more bells and whistles.
results.lead_paragraph: When ''Tron'' opened in 1982, it seemed to offer irrefutable proof that the next cinematic revolution would be digitized and possibly in DayGlo. The movie starred Jeff Bridges as a video game designer sucked into an electronic world (a nice metaphor for an industry that often puts technological trippery above art) that was eye-popping and lid-dropping, with jolts of beauty blazing amid a morass of sluggish storytelling. The main attractions -- bleeding-edge computer-generated imagery and an alternative reality aglow with pulsing phosphorescent colors usually found under the sea or black lights -- pointed toward a brave new world. But the public largely didn't buy into that world, and the film sputtered at the box office. Three decades later Disney has gone back to the electronic drawing board and returned with ''Tron: Legacy,'' a sequel with far less color and cinematic imagination, and many more bells and whistles, including a freakishly special-effected Mr. Bridges going mano a mano in cyberspace with the grizzled real deal. Twice as much Jeff Bridges does not necessarily mean twice as much entertainment -- bummer. But it does offer the sight of the actor returning to the same kind of paycheck-padding gig that landed him in the first ''Tron,'' if without a young man's embarrassment. He's Jeff Bridges, man, and having been summoned to reprise his role as Kevin Flynn, computer genius, he wears a beatific Zen gaze and the look of a man having a pretty good time.

1910 New York Railway Explosion An astonishing and disastrous explosion occurred in the heart of the city this morning [Dec. 19]. Within a few seconds fourteen persons were killed outright and probably 150 others were more or less seriously injured. A gas tank in the power-house of the New York Central Railway in the Fiftieth street blew up, and the scene that followed resembled the aftermath of an earthquake. The dead and dying lay about the streets and sidewalks, and white-coated surgeons from half a dozen of the city hospitals were rushing about attending to the wounded.

results.abstract: Traveling exhibition will showcase photographs and X-rays of historical spacesuits collected by National Air and Space Museum; photos (M)
results.snippet: A traveling exhibition of photographs and X-ray images will put spacesuits in all their complexity on display.
results.lead_paragraph: SUITLAND, Md. -- Stashed in a Smithsonian storage building in this Washington suburb are some of the engineering wonders of the space race. These marvels are far smaller than the towering rockets and streamlined spacecraft that took men into orbit and to the Moon. Far softer, too. They are the spacesuits that kept the astronauts alive beyond Earth.

1910 Wreck of Express Explained A full explanation of the Midland express disaster was given by the signalman, Sutton, who worked the signal-box on the morning of the disaster, at the inquest on the victims, which was resumed yesterday [Dec. 29] and finally adjourned until January 12. The signalman said, according to the ''Daily Mirror,'' that he was very busy on the morning in question. He turned the two light engines, into which the express ran on the down line for Carlisle, and presumed that they went to the advance starting signal. His instructions were to put the light engines ''in block'' and send them to Carlisle. Major Pringle, representing the Board of Trade: ''Did you do it?'' Witness: ''No; I am sorry.''

results.abstract: Paul Calle, one of most highly regarded stamp designers in nation, dies at age 82; photos (M)

headline.main: Paul Calle, 82, Illustrator Of Thumb-Tip-Size Artwork

results.snippet: “When you do a stamp,” Mr. Calle once said of his craft, “think big, but draw small.”
results.lead_paragraph: Paul Calle, a commercial artist whose most famous work was no bigger than a postage stamp, died on Thursday in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Calle, one of the most highly regarded stamp designers in the nation, was 82. The cause was melanoma, said his son Chris, who is also a stamp designer.
